owl:Ontology.dcterms:title: OSLC Namespace for terms in the http://open-services.net/ns/rm# namespace
owl:Ontology.dcterms:description:
This RDFS Schema defines the Open Services for Lifecycle Collaboration Requirements Management and Definition vocabulary, also known as OSLC RM. This vocabulary is a non-normative part of the OSLC RM 2.0 specification, which is part of the OSLC group of specifications.

To comment on this schema, please contact oslc-rm@open-services.net.
owl:Ontology.dcterms:publisher: Open Services for Lifecycle Collaboration Community

rdfs:Class.rdfs:label: Requirement
rdfs:Class.rdfs:comment: Requirements are the basis for defining what the system stakeholders (users, customers, suppliers and so on) need from a system and also what the system must do in order to meet those needs, and how the surrounding processes must be orchestrated so that quality, scope and timescale objectives are satisfied.

rdfs:Class.rdfs:label: RequirementCollection
rdfs:Class.rdfs:comment: Collection of requirements. A collection uses zero or more requirements.

rdf:Property.rdfs:label: elaboratedBy
rdf:Property.rdfs:comment: Expresses an elaboration relationship with a resource. For example, an Architecture Management Resource could be an elaborating model or model element.

rdf:Property.rdfs:label: implementedBy
rdf:Property.rdfs:comment: Expresses an implementation relationship with a resource. For example, a Change Management ChangeRequest, could be an implementing resource.

rdf:Property.rdfs:label: specifiedBy
rdf:Property.rdfs:comment: Expresses a specfication relationship with a resource. For example, an Architecture Management Resource could be a specifying model or model element.

rdf:Property.rdfs:label: specifies
rdf:Property.rdfs:comment: Expresses a specfication relationship with a resource. For example, an Architecture Management Resource could be a specifying model or model element.

rdf:Property.rdfs:label: satisfiedBy
rdf:Property.rdfs:comment: The subject is satisfied by the object. For example, a user requirement is satisfied by a system requirement.

rdf:Property.rdfs:label: satisfies
rdf:Property.rdfs:comment: The subject satisfies the object. For example, a system requirement satisfies a user requirement.

rdf:Property.rdfs:label: decomposedBy
rdf:Property.rdfs:comment: The subject is decomposed by the object. For example, a system requirement is decomposed into a collection of system requirements.

rdf:Property.rdfs:label: decomposed
rdf:Property.rdfs:comment: The object is a partial decompositon of the subject. For example, a sub-system requirement is part of the decomposition of a system requirement.

rdf:Property.rdfs:label: constrainedBy
rdf:Property.rdfs:comment: The subject is constrained by the object. For example, a system is constrained by a safety requirement.

rdf:Property.rdfs:label: constrains
rdf:Property.rdfs:comment: The subject constrains the object. For example, a safety requirement constrains a system.

rdf:Property.rdfs:label: affectedBy
rdf:Property.rdfs:comment: Expresses an affectation relationship with a resource. For example, a Change Management ChangeRequest could describe a defect which affects a requirement.

rdf:Property.rdfs:label: trackedBy
rdf:Property.rdfs:comment: Expresses a tracking relationship with a resource. For example, a ChangeRequest could track a Requirement, by governing changes according to some process defined by a change management system.

rdf:Property.rdfs:label: validatedBy
rdf:Property.rdfs:comment: Expresses a validation relationship with a resource. For example, a TestPlan could validate a requirement collection.

rdf:Property.rdfs:label: elaborates
rdf:Property.rdfs:comment: Expresses an elaboration relationship with a resource. For example, an Architecture Management Resource could be an elaborating model or model element.

rdf:Property.rdfs:label: uses
rdf:Property.rdfs:comment: Expresses a use relationship between resources. For example, a requirement collection may use a requirement.
